text: Betfair management of football is a nightmare. Take last nights West Ham game - suspended for an age, incorrect score displayed and to top it all off they prematurely settled the over 2.5 FHG market and had to correct it later. I tip my hat to any automation that can deal with that kind of nonsense without the use of a paid reliable inplay game feed.

text: VAR has just dragged the game down in general. From an automated betting perspective you have my sympathy! I don't automate football but I do have a few recreational bets on premiereship games. If they eventually ditch VAR I may look at inplay football in future but right now the game and the markets are a mess.

text: You could forgive a dodgy inplayfeed if you knew the market management was sound at the Betfair end. I suppose overall it works but they make some shocking errors with disallowed goals etc since VAR came to the party.

text: so basically need human staff to watch and manage the algos for all the major games?

elements.text: so basically need human staff to watch and manage the algos for all the major games?

text: Why not? I mean prematurely closing a market that subsequently has to be reversed due to a disallowed goal in a top league game has to be seen as a bad error. Suspend the market for sure but do it completely until the decision becomes irreversible. I don't know how it is actually done internally so maybe VAR is just not compatible with Betfair market settlement right now. Even more reason to provide us with unmanaged markets as a side market. We get it with NFL - someone "scores" market goes crazy, play gets reviewed and reversed - all without a market suspension. I just don't get why football is treated in such a different manner. Fine keep the managed markets but at least give us an option with unmanaged ones.

elements.text: Why not? I mean prematurely closing a market that subsequently has to be reversed due to a disallowed goal in a top league game has to be seen as a bad error. We get it with NFL - someone "scores" market goes crazy, play gets reviewed and reversed - all without a market suspension. I just don't get why football is treated in such a different manner. Fine keep the managed markets but at least give us an option with unmanaged ones.

text: not to hijack the main discussion so putting it here. could you please ELI5 (explain like I’m five) whats going on with VAR and why it destroys market making and or automated strats on football.

elements.text: not to hijack the main discussion so putting it here. could you please ELI5 (explain like I’m five) whats going on with VAR and why it destroys market making and or automated strats on football.

text: Its quite simple really. A goal is scored. Then it gets sent for review by VAR. Now firstly, this takes time so estimating game time elapsed is incredibly difficult as a consequence. Market seems to suspend for the most part but there are sometimes periods where it does not suspend and price fluctuates based on 2 potential outcomes. The case seems to be slightly different for things like penalties or sending off of a player but someone else can attest to that as I don't automate, just manually have a bet now and again. Secondly, when a "goal" is scored, Betfair will sometimes prematurely close and settle the corresponding over X.5 goals market. So if you are using market closed status to infer game state your automation is going to have a bit of drama when a closed market suddenly reappears because betfair made a mistake.

elements.text: Its quite simple really. A goal is scored. Then it gets sent for review by VAR. Now firstly, this takes time so estimating game time elapsed is incredibly difficult as a consequence. Market seems to suspend for the most part but there are sometimes periods where it does not suspend and price fluctuates based on 2 potential outcomes. The case seems to be slightly different for things like penalties or sending off of a player but someone else can attest to that as I don't automate, just manually have a bet now and again. Secondly, when a "goal" is scored, Betfair will sometimes prematurely close and settle the corresponding over X.5 goals market. So if you are using market closed status to infer game state your automation is going to have a bit of drama when a closed market suddenly reappears because betfair made a mistake.

text: I wouldn't say it "destroys" it but using the basic betfair feed for score and game time elapsed along with their market closures/status is not always going to be enough to correctly infer an accurate game state. More to the point, you could infer a game state that subsequently reverts to an impossible game state. So a team 2-0 up concedes a goal and it is now 2-1. But that goal is disallowed - that means your automation has to cope with a game being able to go from a 2-1 scoreline to a 2-0 scoreline. Something that you never used to have to worry about.

elements.text: I wouldn't say it "destroys" it but using the basic betfair feed for score and game time elapsed along with their market closures/status is not always going to be enough to correctly infer an accurate game state. text: Of course, but really you want to teach a man to fish. There are some really fundamental things that newbies overlook. For example, use the market to tell you the true price wherever possible (EV calculations, model parameter estimation, statistical arbitrage)

text: Benter's paper

elements.text: Benter's paper

text: None of it is state-of-the-art anymore, and he glosses over some key details (notably parameter estimation - which is non-trivial in his model) but it takes you through a rigorous approach to sports betting

text: <https://www.gwern.net/docs/statistics/decision/1994-benter.pdf>

Cheers - was just digging it out! I also like this forum: <https://www.sportsbookreview.com/forum/handicapper-think-tank/?sort=views&order=desc> Look for the posts by Ganchrow - he approaches things very rigorously. (sort by views and read the most popular old content).
